section-block.rac_essential-question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Carter Goodrich
section-block.rac_book_summary: In this story, Hank the cactus is prickly inside and out! He lives in the desert but doesn’t have many friends. Hank finally starts to feel a bit lonely and changes his ways—find out who will stick around.

section-block.rac_body-text: Practice rote counting from 1 to 20. Count aloud along with the children. If children are proficient counters, have them count up to 10 counters to introduce cardinality.
Go around the circle and ask each child to say his or her name while clapping out each syllable. Say, “Let’s clap Omar. O-mar! Let’s clap Claudia. Clau-di-a!” and so on.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Nobody Hugs a Cactus by Carter Goodrich.
Remember how much Lala loves to read all types of books? Well, she also loves to read narratives, or stories, like this one!
While we read today, your job is to enjoy the story and to listen carefully so you can answer this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Why does nobody want to hug Hank the cactus?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting: As you read the book, place one counter on the floor in front of you each time a new character talks to Hank.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can come to the book and point to a cactus? Would you like to hug a cactus? Why not?
Hank the cactus lives alone in the desert. How do you know he lives in the desert? Why does Hank like the desert?
Who can point to Hank the cactus? How do you think he is feeling? How can you tell? (MB)
Rosie stopped to talk to Hank, so I will add one counter to the pile.
section.rac_body-text: Continue to add counters each time a new character appears.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at Hank’s face—how do you think he is feeling? I wonder why he wants to be alone so badly.
Why did the cowboy say “somebody needs a hug”? Does the cowboy think a hug will make Hank less grumpy and mean?
How did Hank feel at the end of the book? Who will hug Hank now?
Let’s talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Why does nobody want to hug Hank the cactus?
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to the question.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Hank has a lot of pointy sticks coming out of him.
Hank is mean to the animals who stop by to talk to him.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about how many friends passed by Hank’s window.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How does Hank act at the beginning of the story?
Why did Hank change his mind and became friendly?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: To engage with the children’s counting readiness, encourage children to use one-to-one correspondence, counting, and cardinality throughout their day. Children are naturally so curious— asking them to count how many friends, toys, snacks, or pencils they have improves their numerical understandings.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Understand and Manage Your Feelings
section-block.rac_body-text: Managing your emotions in exciting or stressful situations requires learning strategies to cope with these emotions. Teach children self-regulation strategies like deep breathing or removing oneself from the situation. Help children feel empowered to manage their reactions and behave appropriately.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will reread some pages of Nobody Hugs a Cactus by Carter Goodrich. We will think about whether Hank understood his feelings and how he changed his behavior.
Clifford is really good at managing his emotions—he will help us notice how Hank is feeling and what Hank does to manage his feelings.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting As you read, help children count items in the story and say how many there are in all.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s look at Hank’s face and listen to what he says. He wasn’t very nice to the tortoise! How could Hank have acted differently to tell the tortoise that he wanted to be left alone? (MB)
Oh no! Hank is yelling again. What do you think the coyote means when he says that Hank is “as prickly on the inside” as he is on the outside?
The cowboy thinks Hank needs a hug. Have you ever been in a bad mood and someone hugged you? How did it make you feel? (MB)
Rosie helped Hank even after he was rude to her. How did this change Hank’s feelings? (MB)
Do you think it would be “better to be stuck in a hug than stuck all alone?”

section.rac_body-text: Have children play together with some children acting “prickly” while others try to help them feel better. Talk about different things that could make the “prickly” child feel better. It could be a simple gift, a favorite toy, or just a hug.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about feelings and share strategies for managing emotions.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Describe an exciting or stressful situation and give examples and non-examples of appropriate reactions. Practice typical preK scenarios in controlled situations in the classroom so children are more successful when these situations actually occur. Emphasize that children control their own behavior, even when they have strong feelings. (Murphy, 2019)

section-block.rac_body-text: Rote count chorally from 1 to 20. Then go around the circle to count again, this time pointing to different children to indicate it is their turn to count the next number aloud.
Have children stand up. Say a target number you will count aloud until. Have children dance while you count, but freeze immediately when you say the target number.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Nobody Hugs a Cactus.
Lala loves reading narrative stories like this one.
We know that Hank likes living alone in the desert because it is quiet and peaceful. As we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Why did Hank change his mind about wanting to live alone?

section.rac_body-text: Ask children to come to the book to count aloud specific objects. Facilitate back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at the page. How many clouds do you see? What makes the desert so peaceful?
How many legs does that tortoise have? How does the tortoise stop Hank from beginning to relax?
It seems like Hank is starting to change a little. Why do you think Hank asked the owl if he wanted to hug? (MB)
How many papers are blowing away? What happened to Hank? How do you think he feels? (MB)
Hank looks so different than he did at the beginning of the book. Why is he so happy now?
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today? Why did Hank change his mind about wanting to live alone?
section.rac_body-text: Give children time to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to this question.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Hank started to feel lonely living alone.
Hugging Rosie made Hank feel happy.
Hank liked being stuck in a hug.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about how Hank’s feelings changed in the story.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How did hugging Rosie make Hank feel?
Hugging Rosie made Hank feel h___ (happy).
Hugging Rosie made Hank feel happy.
Do you think Hank was prickly on the inside?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children with different home languages or cultures might know how to count proficiently in that language. Help them learn the English numbers by pointing to the corresponding Number Card or Magnetic Number as you say the number word. Encourage children to repeat the numbers after you to become more familiar with the English words.

section-block.rac_body-text: Revisit and discuss Hank the cactus’s many feelings in Nobody Hugs a Cactus. Ask children what they might do if they feel upset or angry like Hank.
Invite children to do a feelings dance. Call out several emotions: happy, sad, angry, scared. Have children do a dance to show each of these emotions in action.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read If You’re Happy and You Know It. It is an informational poster about feelings.
If You’re Happy and You Know It and Nobody Hugs a Cactus both focus on feelings. Let’s look for connections between the two as we read!
Show Nobody Hugs a Cactus book cover.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about this week’s question:
How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask these questions. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How can you tell this girl is happy? What is she doing?
Let’s count the letters in the word happy one by one. How many letters in all?
What is this girl doing? How do you know she is angry?
What can you do to feel better when you want to stop feeling angry? (MB)
I see the word scared. How can you tell this boy is scared?
Sometimes we can be scared to try new things. What can we do when we are scared, but we still want to try something new? (MB) How many letters are in the word scared?
I see the word surprised. How can you tell that this boy is surprised?
What do you like to do when you are feeling silly?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to look at the Big Chart and point to the face that shows how they are feeling right now. Have them draw a picture of themselves that shows how they feel. Encourage them to draw other feelings too!
Provide a writing prompt about feelings and give feedback as children draw and write.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschoolers often experience their emotions physically. They clench their fists when angry or feel a knot in their stomach when sad. But they often don’t know yet how to label these feelings. Guide children to connect physical reactions with the feelings behind them by naming each feeling directly. Knowing what an emotion is can make it less scary to feel!

section-block.rac_body-text: Show children a magnetic number from one to five, but don’t say the number aloud. Ask children to jump, wiggle, or touch their toes that many times while counting aloud.
Have children stay in the circle and use their eyes to “hunt” for numerals one to five anywhere in the classroom. Say each number, and ask where to find it in the room.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and act out Nobody Hugs a Cactus as we read it one last time this week.
Lala wonders if this book tells a story or teaches information. Do you remember?
This week, we learned about counting and the different feelings we have. As we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What would you tell Hank to help him manage his feelings?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read the book one more time together. This time, our friends will pretend to be Hank and his visitors and act out their emotions. Then we’ll count the visitors one more time.
Who is the first visitor? How does Hank treat Rosie? What could he have done differently? (MB)
What did Hank say to the jackrabbit? What would you say if you were Hank?
Why did Hank shout at the cowboy? What could he have said instead? (MB)
Hank tells the lizard he doesn’t want to hug him. But the lizard didn’t ask to hug him!
How many friends have visited Hank now?
What did the owl and Hank talk about? Why did Hank start to feel lonely?
section.rac_body-text: Have children count the “visitors” that helped tell the story.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What would you tell Hank to help him manage his feelings?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Then, ask several children to share with the group.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Hank could count to calm down.
Hank could think of a nice way to say that he wants to be alone.
Hank could take deep breaths before talking to the visitors.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about how Hank’s feelings change throughout the book.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Hank can calm down by taking deep br_____ (breaths).
Hank can calm down by taking deep breaths.
What are some other ways you can control your emotions?

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Counting and Cardinal Numbers
section-block.rac_child_development_body: To help children become more proficient in counting, incorporate fun counting activities in the daily routine. Encourage children to count as they hand out pencils to friends, take steps to the bathroom, or swing on the playground. Encourage them to use their fingers for support when helpful.
